awd_titl_txt: Excellence in Research in Spectroelectrochemical Measurements in Intact Microorganisms
awd_abstract_narration:
Common means of interrogating chemical reactions that occur between solid surfaces and intact microorganisms typically use light in some manner to monitor either color or fluorescence changes that accompany such reactions.  The surfaces of both the solids and the intact microorganisms deflect light and thereby interfere with any optical measurements.  This project will provide and validate a new means to conduct light measurements on reactions between solids and live microorganisms.  A new instrument with an observation chamber that permits all the light measurements to be harvested and measured will be used, rather than simply losing or ignoring the light that is deflected by the solids or particles in the reaction.  This project will focus on 5 to 10 microorganisms that naturally exchange electrons with exterior solid surfaces as part of their lifestyle.  It is anticipated that microorganisms with different types of exterior architectures will exchange electrons with exterior solid surfaces using different strategies and colored biomolecules.  This project will provide a new means to study biological energy transduction under noninvasive physiological conditions without disrupting the complexity of the live cellular environment.  One immediate outcome will be that this project will provide the basic information required to optimize the performance characteristics of microbial fuel cells (novel batteries) at both the anode and the cathode.  Undergraduate minority students will be employed in each of 2 laboratories for this project.   Overall, a minimum of 8 or more minority students will be trained. 
  
The long-term goal of this project is to define the electron transport biomolecules and respiratory pathways in those bacteria that obtain energy for growth from aerobic and anaerobic respiration on soluble and insoluble iron under strongly acidic conditions.  Simultaneous spectroelectrochemical measurements and kinetic studies will be conducted to determine the rates of oxygen consumption as selected microorganisms respire in a combination electrolytic/observation cell.  To accomplish these goals, this project will implement a new methodology that makes it possible, for the first time, to conduct direct spectrophotometric measurements of in situ electron transfer reactions in living cells under physiological conditions as they accept and donate electrons either directly or indirectly via soluble iron to electrodes immersed in the observation cell.  These studies will utilize a novel integrating cavity absorption meter that has an innovative spherical reflecting cavity as its sample observation chamber.  Due to multiple reflections at the cavity wall, scattering losses due to sample turbidity are eliminated or minimized because scattered light is prevented from escaping the detector.  These combined spectral and oxygen measurements will be conducted while the intact microorganisms are oxidizing and reducing during reversible cyclic voltammetry potentiometric scans.  The genera of microorganisms to be studied include, but are not limited to, Acidithiobacillus, Leptospirillum, Acidihalobacter, Sulfobacillus, Ferroplasma, and Metallosphaera, representing 5 of the 6 phyla that contain members that respire on iron.   Prior in situ absorbance measurements demonstrated that each of these five microorganisms appeared to express a different set of colored electron transfer biomolecules to respire aerobically on iron.  Thus, these studies provide the opportunity to compare and contrast 5 different mechanisms/pathways to accomplish the same metabolic goal of respiring on soluble iron.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The general long-term goal of this project is to define the electron transport biomolecules and respiratory pathways in those microorganisms that obtain energy for growth from aerobic and anaerobic respiration on soluble and insoluble iron under strongly acidic conditions.  The genera of microorganisms that were studied included, but were not limited to, Acidithiobacillus, Leptospirillum, Ferrimicrobium, Sulfobacillus, Acidiplasma, and Metallosphaera, representing each of the 6 phyla that contain members that respire on soluble iron at pH values less than 2.0.  Three practical objectives were pursued in this project.

      The first practical objective was to conduct absorbance measurements of iron oxidation using suspensions of each organism as they respired aerobically on soluble iron at pH 1.5.  These measurements were accomplished by exploiting a novel integrating cavity absorption meter that had an innovative spherical reflecting cavity as its sample observation chamber.  Due to multiple reflections at the cavity wall, scattering losses due to sample turbidity were eliminated or minimized because scattered light was prevented from escaping the detector.  Thus accurate absorbance measurements could be conducted in the turbid suspensions of live microorganisms under physiological conditions.  Ferrous ion turns color when it oxidizes to ferric, so these studies comprised steady state kinetic studies using intact microorganisms as the solution catalysts.  The microorganism-dependent oxidation of soluble iron was modeled mathematically using the Michaelis-Menten formalism where the entire intact organism represented the ‘enzyme’ catalyst in the formalism.  Interestingly, values for the turnover numbers and the Michaelis constants for soluble ferrous ions did not vary significantly among the 6 genera investigated.

      The second practical objective was to monitor redox-dependent absorbance changes within each intact microorganism as it respired aerobically on soluble iron.  In particular, we wanted to identify those redox-active colored biomolecules whose absorbance properties changed in such a way they could be correlated directly with the aerobic respiration on soluble iron.  These experiments were very successful.  For the two Gram-negative bacteria (Acidithiobacillus and Leptospirillum), it is generally accepted that electron transfer from extracellular soluble iron to a terminal oxidase within the plasma membrane must proceed through at least 3 components:  an initial iron oxidase in the outer membrane; a periplasmic electron carrier that conducts electrons across the periplasm; and a terminal oxidase in the plasma membrane.  In the case of Acidithiobacillus, all three colored biomolecules were visible, and they changed absorbance in concert such that they behaved as though they were a single unit whose redox state was controlled by a single macroscopic rate constant.  In the case of Leptospirillum, only absorbance changes attributable to the periplasmic electron carrier were observed, suggesting that oxidation of that protein was the rate-limiting step as Leptospirillum respired aerobically on soluble iron.

      For the two Gram-positive bacteria (Ferrimicrobium and Sulfobacillus), there is no outer membrane, only a relatively thick, albeit porous, rigid cell wall framework.  Spectral changes observed with each of these two Gram-positive organisms were consistent with the hypothesis that oxidation of their respective terminal oxidases constituted the rate-limiting step in their respiratory electron transport chains.  Either the terminal oxidases are also the initial iron oxidases in these organisms, or prior electron transfer reactions among upstream biomolecules are sufficiently rapid so as to be kinetically invisible in our absorbance measurements.

      For the two archaea (Acidiplasma and Metallosphaera), their outer membrane architecture is unclear.  In addition to a plasma membrane, both organisms possess a well-defined S-layer, a porous protein layer that is exterior to the plasma membrane.  In the case of Acidiplasma, spectral changes were consistent with the hypothesis that oxidation of its terminal oxidase constituted the rate-limiting step in its respiratory electron transport chain.  In the case of Metallosphaera, at least two redox-active biomolecules were observed that exhibited the kinetic properties expected for direct participation in the aerobic iron respiratory chain.  The bottom line is that these cell studies have revealed that aerobic respiration on soluble iron may proceed by a many as 5 different reaction pathways, each characterized by a unique, distinctive set of different colored biomolecules.

      The third practical objective was to conduct absorbance measurements using the same microorganisms as they exchanged electrons with a solid platinum electrode.  All of these organisms can extract electrons for growth from solid, electron-rich minerals like pyrite (FeS2).  Consequently, we hypothesized that each organism could also exchange electrons with a suitable redox-active alternative surface, such as that of a platinum electrode.  We successfully conducted absorbance measurements when we subjected suspensions of Ferrimicrobium (a Gram-negative bacterium) to repeated cycles of either cyclic voltammetry or chronocoulometry.  The integrating cavity absorption meter was amended to include the 3-electrode system that was required to conduct electrochemical measurements.  The only reduced cellular protein that was visible during the cathodic phases of either the cyclic voltammetry or the chronocoulometry measurements was the same cytochrome as that identified previously when the intact cells respired aerobically on soluble iron.
